channel.title: Port 80
channel.description:
I've tried portforwarding port 80 for a while now. I know how to do it properly but for some reason it won't work for me. I just portforwarded port 80 for devenb123. Here's my router's port forwarding page:
[img]http://i1109.photobucket.com/albums/h440/Fridder2/xampp1.png[/img]
Here's some other pictures..
[img]http://i1109.photobucket.com/albums/h440/Fridder2/xampp2.png?t=[/img]
[img]http://i1109.photobucket.com/albums/h440/Fridder2/xampp3.png?t=[/img] [img]http://i1109.photobucket.com/albums/h440/Fridder2/xampp4.png?t=[/img]
What am I missing/doing wrong? I can visit 123.456.78.0 and it will view my site. (Note this is not my real IP....) If somebody else goes to 123.456.78.0, it will say 'Oops! Google Chrome could not connect to 123.456.78.0" (if they use google chrome). Thank you if you help.

item.title: Port 80
item.dc:creator: @judostar1 judostar1
item.description:
@judostar1 wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:27, topic:417491”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=520048.msg3779129#msg3779129 date=1318305334]
ISPs don’t like letting people use heavy-traffic ports (25, 80, 8080, etc). This is often the reason why you have to pay extra for a plan that allows traffic through those ports.
[/quote]

I paid and port 80 is still blocked. 'the fuck.[/quote]

You can’t open port 80, the xaamp opens it automatically for hosting, and proxies use the port, that’s about it. Portfoward program proof you can’t open it:


Note: I even uninstalled xaamp and my proxy, there is no application using port 80, it is locked, probably too high traffic.

Read full topic

item.title: Port 80

zyle1992:

ISPs don’t like letting people use heavy-traffic ports (25, 80, 8080, etc). This is often the reason why you have to pay extra for a plan that allows traffic through those ports.

item.title: Port 80
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

“OPTIMUM ONLINE minimum system and modem requirements apply.
Optimum Online Boost Plus only available with a subscription to Optimum Online for an additional $14.95 per month. Many factor affect speed. Actual speeds may vary and are not guaranteed. Other restrictions apply. Where available.”

What the fuck? So the speeds may vary and are not guaranteed? So I could be paying $15 a month and have the same as paying $15 less? These guys are like Jagex - money hungry mother fuckers. They act like the port 80 is a plus. They take it away and make us pay to use it, even though we should have had it all along in the first place.

Read full topic

item.title: Port 80
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:23, topic:417491”]Do your other port forwards work? There are many ISPs that block incoming traffic to port 80, so it may not be possible for you.[/quote]Clearly if you read the first post you’d know.

Read full topic

item.title: Port 80
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Do your other port forwards work? There are many ISPs that block incoming traffic to port 80, so it may not be possible for you.

Read full topic

item.title: Port 80
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

A set of port numbers for SMTP (25), HTTP (80 and 8080), and common proxy ports (1080, 3128, 6588) is automatically blocked from external access to the subnet, but may be individually enabled in the web interface. The cost for this service is $24.95/month.

So I have to pay $25 to unblock port 80?

Read full topic

I had to set something else up… besides forwarding the port for my port 80, I cannot remember what it was…

item.title: Port 80
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

^His 43594 & 80 are both ‘105’ at the end, the 43594 one is successful and the 80 one is not.

EDIT: Damnit! Replied faster than me.

Read full topic

item.title: Port 80
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

Spades:

Make sure you are putting in the right IP while port-forwarding

It is, the port 43594 is set to .105 and the port 80 is set to .105 which has the XAMPP shit on it.

Read full topic

item.title: Port 80
item.dc:creator: @Andrew_Ferguson The317Guy
item.description:
@Andrew_Ferguson wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:7, topic:417491”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=520048.msg3776208#msg3776208 date=1318117630]
I did that last year with Xampp for my site, with a linksys router, I had no problem.

Try adding a windows fire wall exception.
[/quote]

I have Optimum Online, I just read that port 80 is blocked along with other ports. There’s an article about this shit. It says it costs $44-$49 monthly, which is a LOAD of bullshit, because I’m paying well over $150 a month, or maybe it was $250. It’s insanely high, considering it was down for a bit under half of a month in late August - early September. If you look at my posts, I made a post August 27, then the next post was September 5 or something.[/quote]
Wish I was on earlier. could have saved you some hassle by telling you that.

Read full topic
